greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Irregular table read by rows, in which row n lists the factorions in base n, for n >= 2.
comment: Because 1 and 2 are factorions in any base, these mark the start of a new row.
link: Karl W. Heuer, Rows n = 2..39, flattened (each row starts with 1 and 2)
example: 49 is in row 5 because 49 = 1! + 4! + 4! and is "144" in base 5.
results.author: _Karl W. Heuer_, Aug 06 2011
